greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle of numbers arising from Gilbreath's conjecture: successive absolute differences of primes (read by antidiagonals upwards, omitting the initial row of primes).
reference: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems Number Theory, A10.
C. A. Pickover, The Math Book, Sterling, NY, 2009; see p. 410.
link: T. D. Noe, Rows n=1..100 of triangle, flattened
A. M. Odlyzko, Iterated absolute values of differences of consecutive primes, Math. Comp. 61 (1993), 373-380.
example: Table begins (conjecture is leading term is always 1):
mathematica: max = 15; triangle = Rest[ NestList[ Abs[ Differences[#] ]& , Prime[ Range[max] ], max] ]; Flatten[ Table[ triangle[[n-k+1, k]], {n, 1, max-1}, {k, 1, n}]] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 23 2012 *)
xref: See A036262, which is the main entry for this array.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
